text:
<@UQL0QDEKA> no I don’t think so. One account, I had had 4 instances of flumine running on two machines at home (gave up on the VPS). One strategy for market recorder, two for live strategies and one for temp/testing. No warnings from the API about connection limits or anything. I don’t my betting patterns were anything weird, one of strategies was placing back and lay bets before the off, the other was placing them after the off.
Why I’m sure it was to do with the political discord is, it was the only place I’ve been posting for the last couple of days, and I was removed instantly from the discord server the second my account was closed.

text: If you want to see self censorship in a corporate world in action, go check out LinkedIn. It’s insipid nonsense for a reason. Most non-social media businesses can not - and will not - tolerate any content from customers, vendors or employees that makes customers, vendors, or employees feel that DEI concerns in respect to their situation is not being dealt with. This isn’t negotiable: you don’t have a right to offend other people. And if you don’t like it, realise that “political correctness” is just a synonym for “politeness”. You can choose who to be polite to and who not to be polite to, but you don’t get to insist on a reaction that isn’t “fuck off”.

text: In respect to conspiracy theories, well, I have some history on dealing with those for other historic reasons. Generally, conspiracies that are discussed in terms of explorations of facts that don’t add up - Roswell eye witness statements, JFK and the magic bullet, and so on - is dealt with by most people who wish to debate them, in a fundamentally different way to those that try and ascribe malicious intent to individuals or groups. Claiming an ethnic group had inside information on 9/11, that the Clintons were involved in a sex grooming gang HQ’ed in the basement of a pizza parlour, or that the Obamas would kill their gardener, are all divorced from facts and asks the reader to think it must be true because “it’s obvious” that “that sort of person” would “definitely” do such a thing. This - and I can’t stress this enough - is abominable and disgusting behaviour, and has no place in civic discourse. It never has been appropriate, social media just makes it move faster.

text: All in all, TLDR: based on just what has been posted here, I think BF were fine doing this. Their fundamental mistake is having a politics forum without a CoC that limits it to facts (polling data, MSM editorials at a push). I’m sorry you’re pushed out of trading, they should have given you clear and precise instructions and has a CoC so you could adjust, but… yeah, with these sorts of posts, I’m not surprised. I think it strange anyone here is.

text:
My first breakthrough came from imagining that the prices on the exchange were invisible and that I had to figure them out from the volumes offered, matched and so on. I worked out a way to do it and that told me what runner would typically look like at a given price in given market conditions. Then I just looked for any instance where my derived prices where significantly different from the best available prices and bet inside the spread on the discrepancy. Over the course of a few years that clocked up over a million quid and since I was penniless at the start that was just magnificent.

The same algorithm isn't nearly as powerful now but I still use it as part of my pricing and as a sense check for a lot of my betting.

I've never repeated the exercise because I'm quite lazy and prefer to do other things but if I did it again I bet it would work again.

elements.text:

I worked out a way to do it and that told me what runner would typically look like at a given price in given market conditions. Then I just looked for any instance where my derived prices where significantly different from the best available prices and bet inside the spread on the discrepancy. Over the course of a few years that clocked up over a million quid and since I was penniless at the start that was just magnificent.

The same algorithm isn't nearly as powerful now but I still use it as part of my pricing and as a sense check for a lot of my betting.

I've never repeated the exercise because I'm quite lazy and prefer to do other things but if I did it again I bet it would work again.

text: Yeah  I didn't say it was easy. I don't know what you've done already so you might be in front of this sort of thing, but one of the things I would do is work through what you might expect in theory and then see if it applies in practice. Say for example that you construct a "toy" market with three runners all matching at 3, how can they be different in other ways and how might you expect those differences to predict the relative value of each runner? Once you've got an idea of what a runner at 3 "should" look like you check that against your data and see if you're right. Don't try to generate bets yet, just see if you can re-price all runners at 3 and see whether in the broadest sense you improved on the market price. Take all the runners at 3 that you made longer - did fewer than 1/3 of them win? Now you know if you're going the right way so you either keep going or change direction.

Say for example that you construct a "toy" market with three runners all matching at 3, how can they be different in other ways and how might you expect those differences to predict the relative value of each runner? Once you've got an idea of what a runner at 3 "should" look like you check that against your data and see if you're right. Don't try to generate bets yet, just see if you can re-price all runners at 3 and see whether in the broadest sense you improved on the market price. Take all the runners at 3 that you made longer - did fewer than 1/3 of them win? Now you know if you're going the right way so you either keep going or change direction.

text: ....then you take that understanding, generalise it to all prices and work out some way to build a whole book. Bingo! Congratulations you've completed the easy part. Now you've got to work out optimal execution and that really is hard.

text: Ok so after what Paul wrote it seems like I might have said too much. While I don’t agree that it’s disgusting to repeat what you read on the news. Most people do, and it seems to matter more who it’s directed at. You can literally say anything about Trump and get away with it, even encouraged. But at the same time I would be ok with being told off and not post stuff like that. This might be par for the course in the corporate world, which I don’t live in. I don’t have training in this type of communication for this day and age. I’m just a retired veteran who sits at home trying to make some money who is passionate about political policies because have so heavily impacted my life and the lives of people I know and once knew
